docs.lead_paragraph: Education is at the top of almost everyone's agenda these days. President Clinton, who rarely misses an opportunity to talk about what he calls ''my No. 1 priority for the next four years,'' has promoted a series of initiatives, from national educational standards to the Hope Scholarship tax credit for college students.

docs.lead_paragraph: DEMOCRATS in the Legislature are still trying to make a comeback from 1991, when voters made them pay for their unhappiness with Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion in tax increases. This year a few races are considered vital if the Democrats are to have any chance of regaining the majority in the Statehouse. There is a slim chance Republicans may lose their 24-to-16 edge in the Senate. Chances of Democrats' winning enough seats in the Assembly to reverse the Republicans' 50-to-30 advantage seem more remote.

headline.main: Some Races Matter More Than Others

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1975 Shelton's largest employer, the sponge-rubber plant that B.F. Goodrich had leased out a year earlier, was firebombed and destroyed in an insurance-fraud scheme, marking the end of the city's smokestack economy and its dependence on a single industry. The fire put 4,500 people out of work. Today, R. D. Scinto, developer of 2 million square feet of offices in Shelton, Trumbull, Fairfield, Bridgeport and Wilton -- half of it in Shelton -- worth a total of some $200 million is Shelton's largest taxpayer and the foremost example of its transformation into a competitor in the Fairfield County office market.

headline.main: In the Region/Connecticut; How Shelton Won a Role in Fairfield's Office Market

docs.abstract: Robert D Scinto's role in transforming Shelton, Conn, former one-industry factory town, into competitor in Fairfield County's office market discussed; his company has just completed its 28th building in area and is at work on another building in neighboring Trumbull; map; photo (In the Region/Connecticut) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE BUDGET That Dissolving Deficit From time immemorial, it seems, the Federal deficit has been growing and worsening, like some malicious creature from a horror movie. Politicians have railed against it. Upstanding Americans, Puritan in economic theory if not in practice, have been distressed -- even if Keynesians said not to worry. Now, suddenly, the deficit is almost gone. It fell to $22.6 billion in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the lowest since $6.1 billion in 1974, as the strong economy brought a surge in tax revenue, Administration officials said. That is a stunning figure, considering that the Administration began the year expecting a deficit of $128 billion. As a percentage of output, less than three-tenths of a percent, it is well below that of any other industrialized nation. Washington's next row presumably will be over what to do with the surpluses expected at the end of the current fiscal year.

docs.lead_paragraph: TAXES Whitman She cut taxes 14 times, including lowering the state's income tax rates by 30 percent and reducing the corporate tax rate. She restored the property tax deduction on state income tax returns.

headline.main: After Months of Running, Marathon Ends Tuesday; The Governor's Race, Issue by Issue

docs.snippet: TAXES     Whitman    She cut taxes 14 times, including  lowering the state's income tax rates by 30 percent and reducing the corporate tax rate. She restored the property tax deduction on state income tax returns.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was elected four years ago on the strength of a bold promise: she would cut state income tax rates by a third. Her opponents said it couldn't be done. She did it in two years, not three. The tax cuts made Mrs. Whitman a national celebrity: the politician who kept a promise. But that has not been enough to appease New Jersey's voters in this fall's gubernatorial campaign. They are fed up with paying the highest auto insurance rates in the nation, and angry that their property tax burden continues to rise.

headline.main: Whitman Stands on Record, But Newer Issues Stir Voters

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''In Vitamin Mania, Millions Take a Gamble on Health'' (front page, Oct. 26), you correctly note an inherent conflict between eating a sensible diet and taking dietary supplements.
